description: Late Middle English cavernous, cavernose, borrowing from Old French caverneux or Latin cavernōsus (“full of hollows or cavities”), from caverna (“a hollow, cavity, cave”) +‎ -ōsus (“-ous, -ose”, adjectival suffix); equivalent to cavern +‎ -ous.

adjectives.description: cavernous (comparative more cavernous, superlative most cavernous)

definitionGroups.group: Resembling a cavern in size, shape, or atmosphere.

entries.meaning: Giving the impression of vast, dark depths.
(anatomy, zootomy) Composed largely of vascular sinuses and capable of dilating with blood to bring about the erection of a body part.
